characters: THE SCREEN GIVES WAY TO ANOTHER FRAME
SUDDENLY, THE RIGHT SIDE OF THE SCREEN BECOMES FULLY
ACTION SCENE TAKES OVER THE WHOLE FRAME.
A GLOSSY, FULL-COLOR COMIC BOOK FEATURING THE TWO MATTRES
THE HARVEY PEKAR WHO WALKS ONTO THE SET IS NOT THE ACTOR
OF THE ABOVE SCENE GRACES THE COVER.
END HIGH DEFINITION VIDEO DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE
IN AN INSTANT, THE CARTOON HARVEY DISAPPEARS AND THE LIVE
SUDDENLY, THE SCREEN SPLITS IN TWO

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: INT. HARVEYВ’S BEDROOM - NIGHT A BEDROOM MIRROR. The room is dark. A perfectly square mirror hangs crooked a wall. Suddenly, out of the darkness, the reflection of a man's  face comes into focus. He stares straight ahead, perhaps  studying his own unrecognizable reflection. It's quite cl this is a portrait of sickness; the man's pallor is gray, his eyes are confused. There is something most definitely wrong. Tentatively, the figure steps away from the mirror, leavi the frame empty and dark.

dialogues.speaker: BED
dialogues.text: Like a ghost, the naked man (Harvey) stands over his bed  staring down at his sleeping wife (Joyce). In the eerie l he's almost translucent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faintly) Joyce... Joyce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce springs up, alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong, Harvey? What are you  doing up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey just stands there for a moment saying nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delirious, out of  breath) Tell me the truth. Am I some guy who  writes about himself in a comic book?  Or am I just -- am I just a character  in that book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce rubs her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I die, will 'dat character keep  goin'? Or will he just fade away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce just stares at him, unsure how to answer. Suddenly  Harvey collapses. Joyce leaps from the bed, nervous, hysterical. She gets d on the floor and shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Omigod, Harvey! Harvey, wake up!

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY'S FACE
dialogues.text: His eyes remain closed, his expression far, far away.

dialogues.speaker: FADE UP ON
dialogues.text: A surreal kaleidoscope of black, white and red. Similar t the mirror scene above, the colors slowly come into focus revealing the chiseled features of a familiar face. But t time we see that it is not a real face, but rather a plas mask of the D.C. Comic hero -- SUPERMAN.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERMAN MASK
dialogues.text: It glows eerily in the light of a porch lamp. A child's p glare through the eye holes... The camera pans from SUPERMAN to the masked face of anoth caped-crusader: BATMAN. Batman turns toward his loyal sid ROBIN, who clutches a plastic, trick-or-treat pumpkin. Next, we find THE GREEN LANTERN as he reaches up to ring doorbell. The camera finally rests on the last boy: an un KID wearing no costume at all. Looking irritated and remo from the rest of the group, the KID shoves his hands in t pockets of his shearling coat. He spits and rolls his eyes as a lady answers the door. The brick home is as working class as it gets. The lady a the door is a 1950's HOUSEWIFE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in unison) Trick or treat!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, look at this! All the  superheroes on the porch! Ain't that  cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lady drops a candy apple in each boy's container.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still yelling) We got Superman here, Batman, his  sidekick ROBIN, ohh, The Green Lantern  even...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finally stops at the costumeless KID. He halfheartedl holds up a ratty, stained pillowcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what about you young man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other boys giggle. The kid flashes them a "kick yer a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you supposed to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kid shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Harvey Pekar (pronounced "Pee  Car").

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey Pekar? That doesn't sound  like a super hero to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling) Pecker, Pecker...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't no super hero, lady. I'm  just a kid from the neighborhood,  alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Housewife stares at him, confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh, forget this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frustrated, the kid throws his pillowcase down. He trudge off as the others watch in confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is everybody so stoopid?

dialogues.speaker: BEGIN NERVOUS JAZZ SCORE
dialogues.text: WE FOLLOW the schlumpy kid (aka HARVEY PEKAR) as he sulks down the street...

dialogues.speaker: INTERTITLE
dialogues.text: A grown-up version of HARVEY PEKAR (now mid-thirties) sto along the same Cleveland street. Unfortunately, 20 years  have made this rust belt neighborhood a bit rustier. The  "GROWN UP HARVEY" dons the same shearling coat, sports th same disheveled hair, and wears the same curmudgeonly  expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is not your typical super-hero stuff. Instead it features our man engaging in such daredevil fe as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Riding the city bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Working as a file clerk at the Veteran's Hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Trying to wash dishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Waiting on line at the supermarket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Buying used records from a garage sale table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Eating junk food at a greasy spoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey fixes a rip in his coat with Elmer's Glue. (Note: Each "Cartoon Harvey" looks similar but unique... variation on a theme. This is because his cartoons are dr by different comic artists.) Intermittently, bold cartoon credits flash across the scr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Followed by the explosive title:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The high-energy music and upbeat titles -- in direct cont to the sulking image of Harvey -- continue through the  remainder of the credits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're now on HARVEY'S back as he continues his forlorn  journey. We move forward, past him, to peer over the hill the factories below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. We're throwing a lot at ya  here, so lemme step in an' help ya  catch up. This is the story about  comic books, an' a guy who made a  whole life outta them. You could  even say comics saved his life. This  guy here, he's our man, Harvey Pekar --  all grown up and goin' nowhere.  Although he's a pretty scholarly  cat, he never got much of a formal  education. For the most part, he's  lived in shit neighborhoods, held  shit jobs, and is now knee deep into  a second disastrous marriage. So if  yer lookin' for romance or escapism  or some fantasy figure to save the  day, guess what? Ya got the wrong  movie.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH DEFINITION VIDEO DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE
dialogues.text: The REAL HARVEY PEKAR (not the actor who trudged through credits) sits behind a microphone, supplying the "voice o above. He clutches a movie script in his hand. The frame is spare, with a few well-chosen items to indic that he's in a recording session. Although he is significantly older than the man who portr him, the "Real Harvey" is every bit as much of a sad sack maybe even more. He is large and slightly threatening wit knitted brows and wild eyes. Yet there is something kind vulnerable about him -- a teddy bear who could kick your  ass. Off Camera, WE HEAR the voices of the male and femal directors (us -- BOB and SHARI) coaching the "Real Harvey through his voice over. Harvey's irritable and contrary,  saying that the whole Halloween incident never even happe "But I don't care man. I'm just doing this for the dough. We learn that Harvey is a reluctant participant in a film being made about his life. SUDDENLY, his third wife JOYCE BRABNER -- an intelligent  control freak obsessed with all things negative -- joins the conversation. Pushing back her huge glasses, she  reprimands Harvey like he is an infant: "Harvey you are  talking too loud, Harvey you are being difficult." Harvey just rolls his eyes. Joyce gets offended. It is clear the have had this argument a million times. As Joyce storms o Harvey explains that his wife is trying to take over the  movie. He laments that she is his third wife, and he has luck with women. "Man, chicks just don't dig me." That's he marries anyone who will have him. "And I marry them fa before they get to know the real me..."

dialogues.speaker: INTERTITLE
dialogues.text: HARVEY sits on a table in his T-shirt and underwear. A DO unwraps a tongue depressor. Harvey's voice is hoarse, raspy and barely audible. It so like it hurts for him to talk. Yet, he can't stop ranting

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc, you gotta help me. My old lady's  dumping me 'cause I can't talk. She  says I'm a social embarrassment. Now  that she's got her PhD, she's some  hot shit academic star an' I'm nuthin'  but a file clerk with nothin' ta say  an' no voice ta say it. But me bein'  a file clerk was fine when I wrote  the damn check for her tuition --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, stop talking please, and  open wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points the tongue depressor at Harvey's mouth but he j keeps on going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just don't get it... We were doin'  okay for a while. Then we took that  stupid belated honeymoon. I started  losin' my voice on the plane. Can  you believe that... On the plane,  doc?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad timing, I guess. Now please say  "Ah," Mr. Pekar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Ahhh." (without missing a  beat) "Ahhh" ruined the trip. I got crazy,  started to worry my voice would never  come back. I mean, my wife didn't  know me so long before we got hitched.  What if she totally forgets what I'm  like? Man, it's torture --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doctor shines a penlight into Harvey's mouth and look around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He raises an eyebrow. Harvey catches this. Hypochondria  overtakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the penlight in his  mouth) What? Is it bad, doc?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doctor removes the penlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey jumps off the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's cancer? First I got marital  problems and now yer tellin' me I  got throat cancer? Omigod...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, calm down. It's not cancer.  You have a nodule on your vocal  chords. Probably from screaming and  yelling too much. And if you don't  stop talking and give it a rest,  you're gonna lose your voice  completely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relieved, Harvey calms down. He nods, agreeing to be good

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whew... Okay, okay. But fer how long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly) Months!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Harvey's voice cracks under his effort to raise He sheepishly grabs his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? More of that and you'll do  permanent damage. Now go home, keep  your mouth shut, and hopefully we  won't have to operate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Operate? Harvey gets nervous again. The Doctor throws him his clothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silent sequence. A dejected HARVEY walks home alone alo an empty lot. Day-old dirty snow clings to the ground. He wanders through a down-in-the-heels neighborhood, pass run-down stores and ramshackle apartments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey approaches TOBY -- a dumpy 20-something going on 6 something in ridiculous, mismatched polyester clothing. H is odd, awkward and talks with a monotone, robotic voice. short, he is a super dork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Harvey. You weren't in work today.  Are you okay, Harvey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey barely looks up. He nods his head "yes" and keeps  walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling after him) I'm heading downtown to the White  Castle. Wanna come, Harvey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey leaves Toby behind and turns the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two WOMEN argue loudly over a payphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) I already told you, I'm waiting for  a call!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Since when is this your  private office?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since you can kiss my ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey stops in his tracks and stares at them, jealous of their ability to speak. CLOSE UP: SPANISH WOMAN #1's MOUTH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Look at 'em yakkin'. How do they do  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of the corner of her eye, WOMAN #2 notices Harvey  eavesdropping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling at Harvey) Ay, what are you looking at? Maricone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Startled, Harvey moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He passes a group of KIDS playing in the snow. They screa yell and laugh with abandon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) They all make it seem so easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, BAM! Harvey is awakened from his reverie by a snowb The kids laugh loudly. He wipes away the snow and walks o A VOICE OVER interrupts the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's our man walking home from the  doctor's. He's got the weight of the  world on him. And fer what, really?  'Cause his throat's a little screwy?  Man, people in India are starvin' to  death every day. His problems are  nothin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally dejected, HARVEY crosses over train tracks on his way home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, he can't help feelin' paranoid,  like some supernatural force is  conspiring against him to rob him of  his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey sulks up the steps of his brick low-rise apartment building. He passes an ELDERLY NEIGHBOR coming down the w with her shopping cart. Harvey unlocks the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe his old lady will go easy on  him today, when she sees how upset  he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey's second wife LANA -- a hippyish chic with long ha and a bad attitude -- pulls books off a shelf and selecti throws them onto the floor or packs them into a milk crat An overstuffed suitcase sits beside her. She's obviously  leaving him. HARVEY enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Ay... What is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey's voice breaks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly what it looks like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud) Whattya mean!! You mean yer dumpin'  me?! Fer what? (his voice really  rips) Ah, shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That last yell did it. Harvey grabs throat in pain, torn  between his throat discomfort and trying to stop his wife from leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, your plebeian lifestyle isn't  working for me anymore. Cleveland's  not working for me anymore. I gotta  get out of here before I kill myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gathers her bags and heads for the door. Harvey trail her, trying to reason. He opens his mouth, but nothing comes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mouthing, just a  wheeze) Please! Wait, honey... Just listen  to what I got to say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and stares at him. Harvey tries to say somethin But now nothing at all comes out of his mouth. Only wheez air. He tries again. No sound at all. Finally LANA gives up, turns back towards the door and le

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At his cubicle in the file room, Harvey fills a cart with files. He's physically at work, but mentally in a daze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's our man -- yeah alright, here's  me -- or the guy playin' me, anyway,  though he don't look nothin' like  me, but whatever. So it's a few months  later an' I'm workin' my flunky,  file-clerk gig at the V.A. Hospital.  My voice still ain't back yet. Things  seem like they can't get any worse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nurse pops her head in. Harvey hands her a file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Harvey dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't hear her, still stewing about LANA. He shoves last files in the cart and pushes it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Plebeian... where the hell did she  get that shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see rows and rows of endless files... Still in a daze, Harvey removes the files from the cart a puts them on the shelves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avoid the reeking herd! Shun the  polluted flock! Live like that stoic  bird, The eagle of the rock!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey turns around. Mr. Boats -- a portly, African-Ameri maintenance worker wearing a bow-tie -- steps into Harvey row. He has a tool box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh. Hiya, Mr. Boats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey resumes shelving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what that means, son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's from an Elinor Hoyt Wylie  poem. It means stay away from the  crowds of common ordinary people an'  do yer own thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Boats laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope, it means don't compromise  yourself for women. Ain't gonna do  you no good! Get away from 'em as  soon as you can!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I ain't got no woman now. So  I'm living like the stoic bird, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only way to live, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somehow this doesn't make Harvey feel any better about hi life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey carries an armful of files. Mr. Boats still trails him, lugging his tool box. Suddenly, Mr. Boats points out a young African-American F CLERK wearing a pair of big headphones on his afro. He mo as if he's listening to music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that fool over there. What's  he wearing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? That's an A.M.-F.M. radio he's  listening to... They got 'em fixed  up now like a pair of earmuffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (inappropriately  angered) MMPH! Isn't that somethin! People  have gone crazy. They'll buy any  kinda junk! Probably listening to  that loud rock stuff. Junk, junk,  it's all junk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know. Rock music's got  some good qualities. I mean it ain't  jazz or nothin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Boats looks at him like he's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, when you gonna bring me in some  good records? Some Nat "King" Cole  with Strings...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't got any of that, Mr. Boats...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Boats stops and yells down the hall at Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you got it... You're keepin'  it at home, though! You won't turn  loose the good stuff... You just  sell the junk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey shakes his head as Mr. Boats finishes his diatribe Mr. Boats turns into a room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) Mona Lisa, Mona Lisa. Men have named  you.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH DEFINITION VIDEO DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE
dialogues.text: Harvey sits on outdoor furniture. A few props are feature in the frame indicating a garage-sale-like setting (inclu a record player). Directly in front of Harvey are boxes o used records. HARVEY shows us his prodigious record collection. Thousan of LP's -- rare jazz, blues, fusion, klezmer, etc. -- are piled in floor-to-ceiling bookcases. He tells us about his love of jazz and how he started wri jazz reviews and music articles. He finds the first recor that he reviewed and puts it on his turntable. As the mus plays... Harvey talks about how he started buying and selling reco This leads into how he first met ROBERT CRUMB.

dialogues.speaker: INTERTITLE
dialogues.text: HARVEY (a little more hair but the exact same style) and bunch of his BUDDIES sift through old records at a junk s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the early sixties I was with some  buddies at a junk sale looking for  some choice sides when I met this  shy, retiring cat from Philadelphia  named Bob Crumb. You know the guy;  Fritz the Cat, Mr. Natural an' all --  they made a movie about him, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of Harvey's pals -- MARTY -- pulls a record out of a  box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Harv. You dig Jay McShann.  You gonna buy that or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey jumps up from his search to check out the LP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Marty. It's got a  lamination crack in it... (checking out the  price) A quarter. Maybe I can get him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are one cheap bastard Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know I'm tight, man, but I  live on a government wage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A skinny guy with a big nose, glasses and a ratty trench  coat taps Harvey on the shoulder. He is soft-spoken, a bi shy and very odd -- a young ROBERT CRUMB.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You collect Jay McShann, man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, man. How 'bout you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah but most of my records are back  in Philly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A greaser-type guy in a leather jacket, PAHLS, joins them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harv, meet my buddy Bob Crumb. He  just moved to town. He's an artist  at American Greeting Card Company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should see his comics, Harv.  They are outta sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interested) Yeah? I'm into comics myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A disheveled mess that gives new meaning to the term bach pad. Records and books are strewn everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Crumb showed me this comic book  novel he was working on -- THE BIG  YUM YUM BOOK. I'd never seen anything  like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY marches back and forth holding Crumb's illustrated comic novel. CRUMB sits on the floor nursing a beer and  sorting through vintage comic books. Harvey's bursting wi so much enthusiasm, it's almost aggressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's terrific, man! I really dig  your work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crumb ignores Harvey's praise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up a vintage  comic) This PETER WHEAT book is by Walt  Kelly... It's pretty rare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Can I get good bread for it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah! Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey flops down in an overstuffed chair. Stuffing flies out. He sips his beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen man, let's get back to your  book. What are you gonna do with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) I hadn't thought about it. It's just  an exercise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey flips through the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's more than an exercise. It's  breaking ground, man. There's some  wild shit in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crumb is immune to Harvey's enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're spitting on me, Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRUMB lies on the couch sketching while HARVEY reads more THE YUM YUM BOOK. A scratchy jazz record plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crumb and I hung out a lot back then.  We had records and comics in common.

dialogues.speaker: CRUMB'S DRAWING
dialogues.text: We see Crumb is actually sketching Harvey, slumped in a c reading a book. Crumb makes Harvey look like a smelly, sw madman with ratty clothing. Crumb holds the sketch of Harvey up to show him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Check it out, man. Pretty scary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey glances up at his portrait, completely unselfconsc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, ya don't know the half of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey goes back to reading. Crumb back to sketching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eventually people got hip to Crumb's  art work and he started hangin' out  with a Bohemian crowd. After a while,  he got sick of greeting cards and  moved away to San Francisco where he  got the whole underground comic scene  off the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crumb slowly evaporates from the room, leaving Harvey tot alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd come back ta Cleveland every  few years, an' people'd treat him  like a celebrity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The record spins and spins...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER R. CRUMB DRAWING OF HARVEY (Now circa 1975) On a sketch pad we see a deranged, tormented Harvey sitti alone on a park bench. He pulls at his hair, and looks as though he may murder the next person who walks by.

dialogues.speaker: INTERTITLE
dialogues.text: As the pencil adds shading to Harvey's face, WE HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once he came to visit when I was  really feelin' bad. It was right  around the time of my throat  operation, an' right after my second  wife left me. At first it was pretty  weird. I mean, here my life was  falling apart an' everything was  going great for him. I was on my  second divorce an' he was a big hit  with the chicks. I was a nothin'  file clerk and he was this famous  cartoonist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY and R. CRUMB sit on a park bench together by a bus stop. A distraught Harvey whines while Crumb just sketche Harvey's voice is still raspy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno, man. On the one hand most  women gettin' graduate degrees  wouldn't give a guy like me the time  a' day. An' she married me an'  everything, so I gotta give her some  kinda credit. But then she got so  mean to me in the end. An' it ain't  like I tried t'keep her captive or  anything like that, y'know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crumb may or may not be listening to Harvey. It's hard to tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An' then on top of it I lost my voice  for three months. I still sound like  shit, but before I had nothin'. Man,  talk about hell. I started forgettin'  what I sound like, y'know? So I  started writin' stuff down -- stories  an' things, my points a' view, ideas.  I even published a couple jazz record  reviews. I guess that ended up bein'  a good thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But don't think I buy into this  "growth" crap. Everybody talks about  how bad experiences can cause ya  t'grow, an' all that clichГ©d stuff.  I've had enough bad experiences and  growth to last me plenty. (a beat) Right now, I'd be glad to trade some  growth for happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment, they both just sit there saying nothing to  each other, each man in his own private universe. Finally Harvey looks over to Crumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how long are ya stayin' in  Cleveland?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crumb never looks up from his picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno, man. I gotta go visit this  chick in New York. And I'm really  busy with the comic book stuff. It's  good bread and all man but I'm getting  fed up with the whole scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are ya talkin' about? Yer makin'  a good living doin' yer art? Sheesh.  How many guys get that lucky in their  life, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I dunno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya know man, people are startin' to  know the name "Crumb." When you croak  you're gonna leave something behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, my ashes and some crappy  doodles. It's not like I'm Blind  Lemon Jefferson or Big Mama Thornton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, man. It sure beats workin' a  gig like mine -- being a nobody flunky  and sellin' records on the side for  a buck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well that's true...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey nods in agreement, mulling this over. He's not at offended.

dialogues.speaker: A FILE DRAWER MARKED
dialogues.text: A hand reaches into the frame and opens the drawer. By rote, HARVEY fumbles with a large stack of "expired  patient" files. He places each into the appropriate  alphabetical "deceased" drawer. Attempting to grab another batch, Harvey accidentally kno the entire pile onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crouches down to survey the mess -- a collage of "expi lives" laid out before his eyes. We move past dozens of anonymous names -- William Anderso Louis Collins, Mark D'Amico, Tyrone Moore, Franklin Ray,  etc... Each file has a red "Deceased" stamp. Depressed, HARVEY is transfixed by the files surrounding on the floor. Suddenly he stops and picks one up. ANGLE ON FOLDER: It is marked, "CHARLIE MARSHALL." He opens the folder and reads the stats... Born: 1920 in Cleveland Died: 1920 in Cleveland Occupatio Clerk ANGLE ON HARVEY: He swallows hard as he reads about Charl small, invisible and now vanished life... He tosses the f back onto the pile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY sits at a table with a pen in hand and a blank she of paper in front of him. Nothing seems to come to him. He flips through a pile of comic books -- everything from D.C. Comic Super Heroes to underground works such as Crum Mr. Natural and Zap Comix. No inspiration. Harvey throws  them down in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm starvin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY pushes a cart through the cramped aisles of a crow supermarket. He pulls a few cans of Beef-A-Roni off the s and heads off to pay. Reaching the check-out area, he  evaluates the situation.

dialogues.speaker: CHECK-OUT COUNTERS
dialogues.text: There are three lines to choose from. Two of the counters have long waits. The third is much shorter but there is a OLD JEWISH LADY next in line.

dialogues.speaker: SUDDENLY, THE SCREEN SPLITS IN TWO
dialogues.text: The LEFT SIDE OF THE FRAME remains Harvey at the supermar deliberating over the check-out lines. However, the RIGHT SIDE OF THE FRAME now contains a CRUMB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: appears over CARTOON HARVEY'S head revealing his thoughts It reads: "Pickin' the right check-out line is an art...  There's a lot of things you gotta consider." ON THE LEFT SIDE OF THE FRAME... Harvey decides to get be the Old Lady. MEANWHILE ON THE RIGHT HAND SIDE OF THE FRAME... Cartoon  Harvey stands behind the Old Lady. A new BUBBLE reads: "It may be the shortest line but I am takin' a chance 'cause she's an Old Jewish Lady." BACK TO THE LEFT SIDE OF THE FRAME... The CASHIER rings u the Old Lady's purchases -- a few kitchen glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Yiddish Accent) Listen, goily, dese glasses are six  for $2.00 because I couldn't carry  twelf... But I vanted twelf so today  I'm buying six more... But you should  only charge me $1.50 for dem... It's  ok, you can esk de meneger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey rolls his eyes and stamps his foot impatiently. He knows he's in trouble now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Frank! I need a price check.

dialogues.speaker: SUDDENLY, THE RIGHT SIDE OF THE SCREEN BECOMES FULLY
dialogues.text: ANIMATED... Instead of still comic panels with balloons, Cartoon Harvey now rants directly into the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, Old Jewish Ladies will argue  forever with a cashier about anything.  Get behind them in a line an' yer  gonna wait forever!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Human Harvey seems oblivious to his cartoon replica. impatiently leans on his cart, waiting and seething.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I'm a yid myself, an' the  women in my family are like that...  But I never got used to it... I may  be cheap, but I got limits!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE LEFT HAND SIDE OF THE SCREEN... The MANAGER finall arrives. The Old Lady haggles with him, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. Let me 'splain von more time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEANWHILE ON THE RIGHT HAND SIDE... The Cartoon Harvey tu to address the Human Harvey, who actually looks him in th eyes. It now seems Human Harvey can actually hear his car alter ego.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up! You're whole life's gettin'  eaten away by this kinda crap! What  kind of existence is this? Is this  all a workin' stiff like you can  expect? Ya gonna suffer in silence  fer the rest a' yer life?! Or ya  gonna make a mark. Huh? Huh?

dialogues.speaker: ACTION SCENE TAKES OVER THE WHOLE FRAME.
dialogues.text: Suddenly motivated by an odd notion, Harvey abandons his  grocery cart and runs out of the supermarket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bursting with ideas, Harvey (wearing his undershirt and  boxers) starts story-boarding his first comic with stick  figures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bleary-eyed HARVEY, still clad in an undershirt and box dozes off over a bowl of Corn Flakes. On the table next t some spilled milk are a stack of papers covered with  scribbling. He clearly has been slaving over this work al night.

dialogues.speaker: PAPERS
dialogues.text: At the top is a quickly scribbled title, "Standing Behind Old Jewish Ladies In Supermarket Lines." These are ad hoc versions of a comic book. The pages are divided like a ti tack-toe board. Each square is filled with crude stick fi drawings and lots of writing. An alarm clock goes off. Harvey's eyes fly open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. Work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey yawns, then notices the pile of papers. He peruses them, proud of his work. He gets up and looks out the win

dialogues.speaker: I/E. HARVEY'S APARTMENT
dialogues.text: It is yet another grey day in Cleveland. The neighborhood run-down. Garbage is strewn everywhere. The following scene unfolds through the window: Two UNSIGHTLY WORKERS lug an old, smelly mattress from a  garage towards the garbage cans on the curb. Their  conversation is distant, but entirely audible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how smart is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno. I guess she's about average.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Average? Hey, man. Average is dumb!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drop the mattress in place. With the window framing  these guys, the scene FREEZES, looking just like a comic  book panel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey turns around from the scene and ponders it. He mov back towards his pile of stick-figure drawings.

dialogues.speaker: PAPER
dialogues.text: Harvey scribbles the words "AMERICAN SPLENDOR" at the top the page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The following scene is shot through the restaurant window We see reflections of people walking by. A tense HARVEY starts at CRUMB as he eats a burger and re Harvey's mock-ups. Harvey doesn't touch his burger deluxe and nervously talks in his laryngitis-afflicted voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, ever since I read your stuff,  man I've been thinking I could write  comic book stories that were different  from anything being done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (munching on a fry) Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinkin', the guys who do animal  comics and super-hero stuff are really  limited 'cause they gotta try to  appeal to kids. And underground comics  like yours have been really subversive  or opened things up politically. But  there is still plenty more ta be  done with 'em, too, y'know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pass me the ketchup?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean with pictures and words, it  could be more of an art form. Like  those French movies are. Or De Sica  over in Italy, y'know?... So I tried  writin' some things about real life.  Stuff the everyman's gotta deal with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crumb finally looks up from Harvey's work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er, yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You turned yourself into a comic  hero?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorta, yeah. But no idealized shit.  No phony bullshit. The real thing,  y'know? Ordinary life is pretty  complex stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crumb reads more. Harvey waits anxiously. Finally Crumb s to chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are really good, Harv.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insecure) Really? Ya think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crumb shuffles through more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. This is great stuff, man. I  dig it. Can I take them home and  illustrate them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey is practically bursting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey's voice breaks like a kid in puberty. He clears hi throat. And something miraculous happens... When Harvey opens his mouth to speak his LARYNGITIS IS GO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd do that for me, man? That'd be  great! I can't draw a straight line!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what's up with your voice, Harv?  All of a sudden it sounds fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thrilled) I don't know, man! I guess you cured  me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY bounds towards the snack room where a group of hos workers and patients hang out. He bangs on the window to their attention. When they look up, Harvey waves a comic  book in the air.

dialogues.speaker: A GLOSSY, FULL-COLOR COMIC BOOK FEATURING THE TWO MATTRES
dialogues.text: GUYS: Scrawled across the top in big red letters reads,  "AMERICAN SPLENDOR. Vol. #1" A man's finger points to the words, "All Stories by Harvey Pekar. Art by R. Crumb." Th comic book sits atop a table in the dreary snack room. A crowd of HOSPITAL WORKERS, PATIENTS, DOCTORS, MAINTENAN WORKERS, etc. (under ten total) gather around a proud HAR who shows off his work. For the first time, he seems almo happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beaming) See that? All stories by yours truly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WWII VET PATIENT with a portable IV cranes to get a gli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot off the presses, huh? We got a  regular Hemingway here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way, Jack, I don't go in for that  macho crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOCTOR #3 chimes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know you could draw, Pekar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah! I don't draw. I just write the  stories. A buddy of mine and some of  his friends do the art work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOBY, the supernerd from the bus stop, grabs the comic bo off the table and peruses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, am I in here? You promised I  would be in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah! Yeah! You're in there, alright?  Jeez, Toby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUDDENLY, MR. BOATS -- Harvey's philosophical co-worker - pushes his way thorough the crowd. He snatches the comic of Toby's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Boats, it's not polite to grab  things. Next time --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, you done good. Ya know, I was  up in Toronto a few weeks back an' I  saw the Red Chinese Ballet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mr. Boats talks, the crowd starts to disperse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that was beautiful. The way those  people were dancing together. Those  Chinese work hard. I tell ya, they  work hard -- Where is everybody goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Boats hands the comic book back to Harvey and turns o his heels. Through the window he notices TWO VETS IN  WHEELCHAIRS moving down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where these sickly men rushin' off  to? They ain't goin' nowhere for  now. Maybe not for a long time. But  damn if they ain't in a rush to get  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey stands there, his moment of glory passed. But it's okay. He flips through his comic and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A motley group of GUYS hang out on a street corner in fro of the Association of Polish Women. HARVEY heads towards  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey look guys, here comes Captain  America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling out) You gonna hang with the boys now  that yer a comic book star?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey turns red. He's embarrassed but part of him loves attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut it out. Man, I ain't nothin' yet  compared to Bob Crumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, listen to him. One lousy comic  book and he wants to be Crumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GUYS laugh.

dialogues.speaker: SILENT GUY
dialogues.text: A SILENT GUY crouches by the wall, reading his CLEVELAND  BROWNS trading cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Harvey, if ya wanna make comics  for adults, ya oughtta put some dirty  stuff in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you can write about Marty's  sex life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey hangs with the guys but he doesn't engage. He seem to be observing them more than interacting with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right Marty? I heard ya went out  with Bonnie yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Howdja do? Wudja git offa her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, lousy. All's I got wuz armaround.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys all stare at him for a moment. Then they crack u

dialogues.speaker: OF THE ABOVE SCENE GRACES THE COVER.
dialogues.text: A MARTY LOOK-ALIKE is bombarded with questions about his  date with Bonnie. He complains that all he got was "arm- around." The REAL HARVEY holds the above comic book in hi hand. The stage is set with a few items that indicate a c book store. HARVEY talks about a couple of "American Sple issues and how they impacted his life -- recognition as a writer, etc. He gives his philosophy about the comic book etc. A MONTAGE OF AMERICAN SPLENDOR COVERS (ISSUE #3, #4, #5, #6, ETC.) THEY INDICATE A PASSAGE OF TIME...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY sits alone in his cubicle. He doodles stick figure on a pad -- some ideas for a new comic. His posture's  miserable. He rubs his temples like he's in anguish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's our man eight comics later, a  brand new decade, same old bullshit.  Yeah sure, he gets lots of recognition  for his writin' now. Sure his comics  are praised by all the important  media types tellin' people what to  think. But so what?  It's not like  he makes a livin' at it like Bob  Crumb. He can't go an' quit his day  job or nothin'.

dialogues.speaker: JUMP CUT SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: Several shots of Harvey just thinking, scratching his fac with a pencil, tapping his foot nervously. Each shot is separated by a second or two of black (an ho to Harvey's wordless panels). Finally, he goes back to  writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who am I kiddin'. Truth is I'd be  lost without my work routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone in bed, Harvey wakes up in a cold sweat from a  nightmare. He looks horrified, short of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calming himself down) I got a job... I got a job...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY scratches his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey writes "I got a job" in a balloon over the stick  figure's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So -- to stave off desperation and  feelings of uselessness -- I resigned  myself to a menial existence. But  hey, maybe the guy who's had a happy  life feels worse just before he dies  than th' guy who had a sad one. Or,  maybe not. I dunno. Maybe I just  needed a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby comes in, decked out in plaid and stripes. He has an empty messenger bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Harvey. Do you want these gourmet  jelly beans? I gave up sweets for  lent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey turns around. He seems down, depressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Sure, I'll take 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby watches Harvey eat a few.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, watermelon. That's pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I recommend the piГ±a coladas. They  are excellent and very authentic  tasting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby heads down a file row and proceeds to take a few off the shelves, stuffing his bag. Harvey gets up and comes a him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Toby, can you eat lentils during  lent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. I don't see why not. You can't  eat meat on certain days, but lentils  should be acceptable anytime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya think there's any connection  between lentils and lent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so but I'll ask Sister  Mary Fred at church on Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sister Mary Fred, huh? Is she cute?  Sounds kinda mannish but who am I to  be picky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, you're funny. She's a nun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what? Maybe she became a nun  because she couldn't get a guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, she became a nun because she  had a higher calling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Higher calling. That is such a crock  of shit. I don't know why you waste  your time prayin' anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Harvey, I like the ritual. And  I'm a very spiritual person. You  know, you should try believing in  something bigger than yourself. It  might cheer you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby turns on his heels and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after him) What? Do I seem depressed, Toby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby doesn't respond. Harvey shrugs and digs deep into the jelly bean bag. He p out a fistful.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY'S HAND
dialogues.text: Jellybeans in every imaginable color. Harvey fingers a fe and then picks a blue one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut!

dialogues.speaker: HIGH DEFINITION VIDEO DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE
dialogues.text: A few items from the previous scene are present on the so stage indicating that it's a set of AMERICAN SPLENDOR -- Movie. THE ACTOR HARVEY stands alone, his hand filled with Jelly beans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, that was great. The bakery  scene is next...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ACTOR HARVEY steps out of the frame, revealing a craft se table behind him. At the table, the REAL HARVEY and the R TOBY load up on donuts. The two discuss the food on the s Ironically, the Real Toby is actually more extreme than t Actor who plays him -- even more robotic, and completely  incapable of eye-contact. The REAL TOBY discusses the finer points of nerdom and  evaluates the Actor's nerd quotient. The Real Harvey expl to Actor Toby that nothing -- not even gourmet jelly bean would have cheered him up at that point in his life. He was too lonely and depressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light pours through the curtained window. Naked and disheveled, HARVEY tosses and turns in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My loneliness was unbearable, man.  Weekends were the worst. Sometimes  in my sleep, I'd feel a body next to  me like an amputee feels a phantom  limb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extreme wide shot: a city-street overpass spans across th entire frame. The lone figure of Harvey sulks there in th middle, watching traffic pass below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure my comics were bringin' me  notoriety, but my personal life was  in shambles. I thought a little  attention would make me feel better.  It only made me feel worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a beautiful, sunny day. The trees are in bloom. There's the first scent of spring in the air. Kids play i the street. Music pours out of passing cars. Everyone see to have a smile on his or her face except HARVEY. He walk on the shadowy side of the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shot of HARVEY trudging into the bakery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of WOMEN order bread and cookies from TWO COUNTE GIRLS. HARVEY surveys the donuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling to Harvey) Next!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Counter Girl) Yeah! I'll have two crullers, a jelly  donut with powdered sugar... And you  got any "day old bread"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman with attractive Irish looks brushes past Harvey o her way to the door. This is ALICE QUINN, roughly Harvey' age but there is a tired, weary look in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you're Harvey Pekar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half in a daze, Harvey stares at the chick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice Quinn. From school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey studies her face. Suddenly, it clicks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. College. We had a couple  lit classes together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey pays and receives his items. They step back toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to you? You just  disappeared after one semester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey scratches his armpit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, man. I got good grades and  all but there was this required math  class. I can't do math, an' that  required class hangin' over my head  made me crazy. Eventually the pressure  got to be too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're doing okay anyway. I  heard all about your jazz reviews  and your comics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This perks Harvey up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, you're famous. Meanwhile I got  my degree but I'm just a plain old  wife and mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey stares at her wedding ring. His face drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I'm not doing as great as ya  think. My second wife divorced me  and I work at a dead end job as a  file clerk. Sometimes I hang out  with the guys on the corner but most  of the time I just stay home by myself  and read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're luckier than you think. My  husband and kids make it impossible  for me to cuddle up with a good book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY and ALICE continue their conversation as they stro towards her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm reading this book by Dreiser now --  JENNIE GERHARDT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's one of my favorites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope it don't end like so many a'  those naturalist novels... With  someone getting crushed ta earth by  forces he can't control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'll be pleasantly  surprised. It's certainly not a  Hollywood happy ending, but it's  pretty truthful. Which is rare these  days...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This hits home with Harvey. He can't believe he's made su a connection with this woman. Alice stops in front of a beat-up station wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice car. I don't have one yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I give ya a lift somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah. It's a nice day. I'll just walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey looks down, a little sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we should have you over sometime  for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I'd be glad t'come. But if you  really wanna do me a favor, introduce  me to some a' your single girlfriends.  I bet they're all smart like you.  I'm no catch, though, so I'll take  anything you can get me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice pecks Harvey on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll work on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice seeing ya Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey watches as she drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I got home, I finished reading  JENNIE GERHARDT. It was real good,  way better than I expected. That  Alice wuz right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is moody, dark and lonely. The shadowy figure of Harvey sits on the floor devouring JENNIE GERHARDT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure Lester -- the main character --  croaks in the end, but at least he's  old and dies a natural dignified  death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA TRAVELS AROUND THE ROOM TO FIND: Harvey again, now silhouetted in the door frame, still clutching the bo and obsessed by his thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was more alone that weekend than  any. All I did was think about JENNIE  GERHARDT an' Alice Quinn an' all the  decades of people I have known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA TRAVELS AGAIN TO FIND Harvey sitting on a chai in the corner of his room. His head is bowed. His shoulde slump over, as if he's struggling with something weighty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The more I thought, the more I felt  like cryin'; Life seemed so sweet  an' so sad an' so hard t'let go of  in the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA TRAVELS A FINAL TIME TO FIND: Harvey sprawled  across his couch. But he's not asleep; he's still obsessi The book lies on his chest like a lover. CLOSE UP of Harvey's troubled face. Beneath the pain, we hope and determination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But hey, man. Every day's a brand  new deal, right? Just keep on workin'  and sump'n's bound ta turn up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An urban comic book shop on a dicey but bohemian street. title over picture reads, "MEANWHILE, IN DELAWARE."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOYCE BRABNER, a depressive nudge with a perpetually pept expression frantically searches the store for something. partner, a granola type named RAND, finishes unloading a  stack on the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to the new American  Splendor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We sold 'em, babe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (accusatory) Damn it! I put one aside for myself,  next to the register. I didn't even  get a chance to read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, sorry, Joyce. I didn't know  you were such a Splendor fan. Next  time take it home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce leans against the counter. She pushes up her glasse and looks really upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'll call the publisher. But  they take so damn long. Shit! Why  does everything in my life have to  be such a complicated disaster...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce starts slamming things around the store. Finally Ra grabs his stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm gonna hustle before the  vibe in here gets any worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rand leaves. Joyce barely notices, still brewing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mess in this room rivals Harvey's. A few cats add to clutter. Joyce lies on her disheveled bed and writes a le

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greetings from the second smallest  state in the union, an endless  plastics and nylon plantation  controlled by giant chemical  corporations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY takes his mail out of the box. He finds an oddly  decorated envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To make matters more dismal, there  are no decent comic book stores in  my town, which is why my partner and  I opened one ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY finishes reading the letter sitting on the toilet. cat runs around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite our steadily faltering  business, my partner managed to sell  the last copy of American Splendor  #8 out from under me. I'm a big fan  and I hate to wait for a new order.  Is there any way I can get it from  you direct? Sincerely, Joyce Brabner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey scratches his head. He mutters to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...man, she's got good lookin'  handwritin'...

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY AND JOYCE COMMUNICATING
dialogues.text: We see Harvey in his bed writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Joyce, Thanks for the letter.  Whattya do besides sellin' comics?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Joyce standing in front of a GROUP OF PRISONERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a sometime activist and I teach  writing to prisoners. I try to help  them build an interior life and make  art out of their monotonous,  suffocating routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey scribbles a letter while riding on the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds familiar. So you married or  what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce empties her can of cat food in a plate and slides i towards her kitty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm divorced, thank god.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we see Harvey (full screen) in bed in his underwear  talking on the PHONE. He's clipping his toe nails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I think you an' I got a lot in  common. How am I gonna get you to  come visit me in Cleveland?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cleveland? You think that's a good  idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a great idea. You should meet  me, 'cause I'm a great guy. Despite  the way my comics read, I got a lot  of redeeming characteristics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLIP! He clips off a big one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce sits on her equally disheveled bed dunking a tea ba Her hair is wet from a shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Where would I stay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With me. Don't worry, I'm not gonna  put no moves on you or anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not worried about that... (fumbling with a tea  cup) Hold on, I just spilled chamomile  tea all over my bathrobe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are ya worried about then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce sighs and lies down. A variety of AMERICAN SPLENDOR are across her bed. Different interpretations of Harvey s up at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sipping) Well, the way all those different  artists draw you, I don't quite know  what to expect. I mean sometimes you  look like a younger Brando, but then  the way Crumb draws you -- like a  hairy ape with all those stinky,  wavy lines radiating off your body --  it's kind of scary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are motion lines. I'm an active  guy. Anyway, just come out here an'  I'll try to be anyone you want me ta  be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce smiles for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a dangerous offer. I'm a  notorious reformer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nervous JOYCE walks off the plane into the arrivals are She scans the crowd of friends, family, lovers and limo  drivers waiting to meet the disembarking passengers. Wher is Harvey? What will he look like? As Joyce surveys the unfamiliar faces, she imagines diffe versions of an animated, illustrated Harvey among the peo She double-takes as sees the R. CRUMB HARVEY -- hairy, sc smelly and picking his nose. Joyce rubs her eyes. Next she sees the BRANDO HARVEY (Gary Dumm), but unfortun he disappears fast. Disappointed, Joyce notices the realistic DREW FRIEDMAN H walking towards her. She smiles as he dissolves into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Are you Joyce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce turns around. The flesh and blood HARVEY PEKAR stan before her -- not quite as bad as the Crumb version, not  quite as good as the Dumm version, but still acceptable. sighs with relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Harvey. We finally meet in person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She politely offers her hand. Harvey shakes it, but he lo overwhelmed, worried and pessimistic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya. Look, before we get started  with any of this, ya might as well  know right off the bat. I had a  vasectomy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce lets go of his hand. She stares at him in disbelief

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The most awkward date in history. Seated in an ultra-yupp restaurant filled with business lunchers, Harvey and Joyc hide behind their menus. While everyone else looks slick successful, these two compete for the world's worst postu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somethin's wrong. Yer lookin' around  everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I never imagined you eating  in a place like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? I never been here. I thought  you'd like it. But obviously ya don't,  do ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine. What difference does it  make?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey shakes his head, feeling more pessimistic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno. None, I guess. (beat) They sure got a lot of meat on this  menu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a vegetarian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kinda. I mean ever since I got a pet  cat, I couldn't eat animals anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce grabs a bread stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm. I support and identify with  groups like PETA, but unfortunately  I'm a self-diagnosed anemic. Also, I  have all these food allergies to  vegetables that give me serious  intestinal distress. I guess I have  a lot of borderline health disorders  that limit me politically when it  comes to eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey just stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. Yer a sick woman, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet. But I expect to be. Everyone  in my family's got some kind of  degenerative illness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cheery waitress bounces over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sing song) Good afternoon! I'm your server Cindy!  What can I bring you two today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They slowly look up at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOYCE and HARVEY enter the apartment. The place is a mess as usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I was gonna clean up, but why  should I give you any false notions?  The truth is I got a serious problem  with cleanliness. I could wash a  dish ten times and it'd still dirty.  They even kicked me outta the Army  'cause I couldn't learn ta make a  bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce puts down her bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slumps down on the sofa as if she's been here a milli times. She rubs her head. Harvey sits next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, go get me water and a few  aspirin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey just bounces back up and obeys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, ya got a headache?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I want to avoid one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey empties the aspirin bottle in his palm. For some  reason, he's feeling more comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well lemme tell ya Joyce, it sure is  nice ta have company. I mean, despite  all your problems, you seem like a  great person. An' hey, sorry if my  dating skills are kinda rusty, but  I've just been through hell and back  with women. I mean that last one  turned out to be a real nasty bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey arrives back with the aspirin. He hands it to Joyc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a nice time with you, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce swallows the pill. Harvey sits down next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? You had a nice time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make people repeat themselves.  It's annoying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're inches away from each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls him close. Harvey plants a kiss on her. They slowly separate. Joyce's eyes are closed. She likes  him. He kisses her again. They start making out, moaning bit. But before it gets heavy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce opens her eyes. She looks uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which door's the bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey stands by the bathroom door, despondent. From insi we hear the sounds of moaning and flushing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Joyce! What's wrong? What is  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLUSH! Joyce is doubled over on the toilet. She's looking green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh! I don't know. I think that yuppie  food did me in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel terrible. Lemme at least do  something for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce gets to her feet and puts her glasses back on. She  picks up a can and sprays air freshener around the room. Then she looks at the can and realizes it's WD-40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I make ya something? How about  some chamomile tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce puts the can down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chamomile tea? What the hell's a guy  like you doing with that? I thought  you drink soda pop for breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno. I noticed you drank a lot  of it when we started talkin' on the  phone. So I stocked up on herbal  teas for your visit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce turns her head to the door. She's truly surprised b what Harvey's just said. And very moved. She smiles to  herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey stands there waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl at the Food Co-op picked me  out all kinds of herbal stuff. One  of 'ems good for stomachaches. Grandma  Bear's Tummy Mint, I think. Are you  still there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce slowly opens the door. She leans against the door f like she's just been through a war. She takes off her glasses and cleans them off with her sh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, we better skip this whole  courtship thing and just get married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey and Joyce are in bed, lying in each other's arms. They look quite contented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, am I glad I talked you into  comin' up here. Any more time alone  and I mighta lost it fer good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you don't have any problems with  movin' to Cleveland?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. I find most American  cities depressing in the same way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An' yer okay with the vasectomy thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY approaches the building. Instead of dragging his f like usual, he seems to be floating on a cloud. We haven' seen Harvey this happy since... well, since never. He stops by a junker car and peeks in the window, finding TOBY eating lunch alone. He has an entire White Castle  smorgasbord spread across the front seat. Harvey knocks on the window. Toby rolls it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ay Toby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mouth full) No you can't have any of my White  Castle hamburgers so please don't  even ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have a fry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey reaches for a handful of Toby's fries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, but just a couple, Harvey. I'm  not going to eat dinner until very  late and this has got to hold me  over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey leans in, always amused by Toby. He steals another fry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (munching) Whattya got, a church function?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm driving to Toledo to see a  movie. Would you like to come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah. I gotta fly to Delaware tonight.  I'm gettin' married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Why Delaware?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chick I'm marryin' is from  Wilmington. Plus, I gotta help her  move her stuff here. (a beat) Why you drivin' ta Toledo to see a  movie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not playing at the Mapletown. (a beat) I didn't know you had a girlfriend,  Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. We met last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey opens the car door and slides in with Toby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby, what movie could possibly be  worth drivin' 260 miles round trip  for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a new film called "Revenge of  the Nerds." It's about a group of  nerd college students who are being  picked on all the time by the jocks,  so they decide to take revenge. I  already saw it once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, ya really dig this movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it a lot, Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are these nerds like? How would  you describe them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm... Nerds are smart but they look  and act differently than other people.  Like nerds might wear polyester button- down shirts and flood pants where  their ankles and their socks are  showing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby spills some catsup on his polyester button-down shir He stands up to get a napkin, revealing his flood pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what yer sayin' is you identify  with those nerds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rubbing out the catsup) Yes, I consider myself a nerd. And  this movie has uplifted me. There's  this one scene where a nerd grabs  the microphone during a pep rally  and announces that he is a nerd and  that he is proud of it and stands up  for the rights of other nerds. Then,  he asks the kids at the pep rally  who think they are nerds to come  forward... So nearly everyone in the  place does. That's the way the movie  ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the nerds won, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey grabs the rest of Toby's fries and opens the door leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. You got this movie an' I'm  gettin' hitched. We both had a good  month, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finishing his last  burger) Right. Harvey, how long are you going  to be in Delaware because I'd really  like to see this movie with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only goin' for a week but then  I'll have a wife, so I'll have to  take her along. Is it a girl flick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Depends on the girl. What kind of  girl is your new bride? Is she a  nerd?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, man. Maybe. She's into  herbal teas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby watches Harvey saunter off. He returns to his last  hamburger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brightly lit marquee reads, "REVENGE OF THE NERDS." The doors to the theater open and a crowd pours onto the stre HARVEY, JOYCE and TOBY are among them. Toby proudly wears "Genuine Nerd" button on his striped shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree with Toby. I think it's a  story of hope and tolerance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It's about time that the people  who get picked on get to be the  heroes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey scrunches his face in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an entertaining flick an' I can  see why you like it Toby, but those  people on the screen ain't even  supposed to be you! They're college  students whose parents live in big  houses in the suburbs. They're gonna  get degrees, get good jobs and stop  being nerds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce hits Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, what did I say about loud  talking? Use your inside voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering loudly) Look Toby, the guys in that movie  are not 28-year-old file clerks who  live with their grandmothers in an  ethnic ghetto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough, Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They didn't get their computers like  you did -- by trading in a bunch of  box tops and $49.50 at the  supermarket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce folds her arms in disapproval. Toby starts to laugh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're funny Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey looks at him, disappointed. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Toby. Go to the movies and  daydream, but "Revenge of the Nerds"  ain't reality. It's just Hollywood  bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY'S CAR, (THROUGH WINDSHIELD)
dialogues.text: Toby and Joyce continue to analyze the movie in the front seat as Toby starts the ignition.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY IN BACK SEAT
