dialogues.text: Slouched, grumpy and alone on the back seat, Harvey's sti annoyed by the movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, maybe I was bein' so harsh on  Toby onna count a' my own problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'see, I wasn't even married a month  and my old lady was already showin'  signs a' trouble. Granted, I tend ta  get married fast 'cause I'll take  any woman that'll have me, but this  time I really met my match...

dialogues.speaker: HIGH DEFINITION VIDEO DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE
dialogues.text: A few items indicating film production are in the frame. At a table in the foreground, BOB THE DIRECTOR discusses character of Joyce with the ACTRESS playing her. The actr just nods as the director goes on. We can see THE REAL JOYCE sitting with THE REAL HARVEY in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I think the thing with Joyce  is that as manic as Harvey can be,  she matches him with depression. In  that way they complete each other. I  mean, she's obviously a very smart  woman, but she has a lot of trouble  functioning in a world she can't  control. And she's totally obsessed  with all things negative; y'know,  diseases, dysfuctions, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE REAL JOYCE and REAL HARVEY listen curiously -- someti pleased, sometimes displeased -- as their personalities a dissected and boiled down to a few phrases.

dialogues.speaker: REAL JOYCE AND HARVEY
dialogues.text: The REAL JOYCE puts in her two cents about the actress pl her. She rants about what it's like to be portrayed in a  movie, and having a character arc imposed on her life. She moves into talking about her relationship with Harvey and the first years of their marriage -- how impossible i was to live with him. The REAL HARVEY just rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOYCE is on a cleaning rampage. She rummages through pile upon piles of records while HARVEY paces nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about these 78's, Harvey? Can't  you sell them to one of those  collectors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are ya kidding? No way, man. I ain't  getting rid of my 78's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce throws down the records in frustration. Harvey runs over to check if they're scratched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) Forget it then. I give up! How can I  make more storage space, if you won't  get rid of anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get rid of stuff. Just not my  good stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's your good stuff. How am  I supposed to live here, if there's  no room for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw come on, baby. I'll make room for  ya. You just have to give me time.  I'm not so good at these kind of  things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because you're obsessive  compulsive Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DOOR BUZZER rings. Harvey slams it to unlock the front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon. I don't wanna hear that  psychobabble crap!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care if you wanna hear it or  not. You're the poster child for the  DSM III. I'll have you know that I  come from a very dysfunctional family.  I can spot personality disorders a  mile away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A KNOCK ON THE DOOR interrupts their argument. Joyce stor away to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR
dialogues.text: Joyce opens it to face a smiling TOBY -- dressed as usual a loud polyester fashion don't. He talks in his strange  robotic voice and avoids all eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Joyce. Is Harvey home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce turns to Harvey and points to Toby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Borderline autistic!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This scene shrinks into a square up in the corner. The ne few scenes (NEUROSIS MONTAGE) further divide up the full  screen like a comic book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: R. CRUMB leaps from behind an autograph table (where he's signing comics) to hop on the back of ZAFTIG BABE, who of him a piggy-back ride. Joyce turns to Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Polymorphously Perverse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOYCE picks up Harvey from work. HARVEY enters the car, w goodbye to the ranting MR. BOATS. She points to Mr. Boats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paranoid Personality Disorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE TELEPHONE RINGS. A disheveled, tired-looking JOYCE fl through a novel and lets the machine pick up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please leave a message. (Beep)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hey Joyce, it's me. You're not gonna  believe this but some LA producer  called an' he wants to do a play  about my life. Call me! (Click)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce flips the page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself) Delusions of grandeur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: END NEUROSIS MONTAGE (return to full screen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY and JOYCE sit in a packed theater watching a play. Joyce looks exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE
dialogues.text: A STAGE ACTOR HARVEY and a STAGE ACTOR JOYCE share a couc on the sparse stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, I think comics can be an art  form. With pictures an' words, a guy  can do pretty much anything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's true, Harvey. But I didn't  come all the way from Delaware to  talk about comics ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "Stage Actor Joyce" lunges over and plants a kiss on  him.

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY AND JOYCE IN AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: Harvey digs it but Joyce looks disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO STAGE
dialogues.text: We now see STAGE ACTOR HARVEY clutching a tea cup, as STA ACTOR JOYCE kneels before a toilet bowl. Off to the side the stage, A SPOT LIGHT illuminates a GUITAR PLAYER, who  adds music to the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY and JOYCE walk through the terminal. Harvey brims  with energy but Joyce looks exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If ya think readin' comics about yer  life seems strange, try watchin' a  play about it. God only knows how  I'll feel when I see this movie. But  truth be told, the play wasn't half  bad, and we got a free trip outta  it. Things were goin' pretty good  for a change. Variety called me "The  Blue Collar Mark Twain," and Doubleday  was interested in publishing an  anthology of "American Splendor."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey nervously taps his foot as he waits for the bags. Joyce leans against the carousel staring at a YOUNG MOTHE with a BABY in a Bjorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate checkin' bags, man. It always  takes forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He checks his watch. Joyce remains quiet and distant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, look at the time. The bus is  gonna leave soon and there won't be  another one for an hour. That means  I gotta shell out an extra thirty  bucks for a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey spots a bag that he thinks is his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey wait, there's our -- (a well-dressed man  grabs it) Figures. That lucky Yuppie's gonna  get on the bus in time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Joyce mumbles something to Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know Harvey, vasectomies are  reversible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring her) Damn Yuppies get everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising her voice) Are you listening to me? I said  vasectomies are reversible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heads turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Whattya talkin' about? I don't  want kids. An' I came clean about my  vasectomy the first time I set eyes  on ya', right here in this airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More heads turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know but things have changed. I  think we can be a family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Family?! What kinda family could we  possibly be? I ain't no good with  kids. I can barely take care of  myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take care of the kid and you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dead serious) No way Joyce. Forget it. I can't do  it; I can't have no kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce folds her arms... dejected, defeated. The audience eavesdroppers looks disappointed as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the place was a disaster before, believe it or not, it gotten worse. JOYCE seems to have given up on her  organizing... and everything else for that matter. HARVEY hysterically searches through the mess for a recor album. Joyce just lies listlessly on an open futon on the middle of the room; it looks as if she hasn't been up in  days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the hell is that Ornette Coleman  album, Joyce? I got a review due  tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce rolls over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't touch it, Harvey. Would you  let me sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's one o'clock! How late can a  person sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce sits up. This time she means business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It happens to be Saturday you selfish  sonofabitch! And don't you go telling  me what to do. I'm the one who moved  into your city, into your home, into  your vasectomy and into your screwed- up life. The least you could do is  allow me to live here my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rolls over and covers her head with the pillow. Harve just stands there staring at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried everything but nothin' could  get this woman outta bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY peruses the aisles. He pulls box upon box of herba tea off the shelves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean she wouldn't get a job,  wouldn't go out, wouldn't make  friends, nothin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY throws boxes of herbal teas at JOYCE as she sprawl listlessly on the futon. She just yawns and turns over on her side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce diagnosed herself as "clinically  depressed." I don't know what the  hell she was goin' through but it  was sure takin' it's toll on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A frustrated Harvey tries once more to cheer her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (upbeat) We can go out for dinner tonight.  How 'bout catching a bite at Tommy's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling) I'm not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey throws his hands in the air and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I give up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he passes the answering machine, he notices it's blink

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Joyce, we got a message here.  Why didn't you pick up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Useless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He presses the play button. ANGLE ON ANSWERING MACHINE: A loud "beep," then ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, this is a message for Harvey  Pekar. My name is Jonathan Greene  and I'm a producer for LATE NIGHT  WITH DAVID LETTERMAN. We'd like to  talk to you about coming on the show  to plug your comics. Please give me  a call at 212-555-3333.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce sits up. Harvey's finger hits the "Replay" button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, this is a message for Harvey --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The impressive skyline glistens in the spring sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce finally got off the futon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armed with shopping bags from Bleecker Bob's Record Shop, the Strand Book Store and Forbidden Planet Comic Book  Emporium, HARVEY and JOYCE eat lunch on a park bench. Har chomps on a knish and watches oddball New Yorkers stroll as Joyce nibbles on her hot dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut back to reveal Harvey, schlepping an ice bucket down hall in his underwear. A FEMALE BUSINESS TRAVELER passes stares at him. He enters a room with a "DO NOT DISTURB" s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PEKARS have already wreaked havoc on their luxury hot room. It looks like a tornado touched down on the New Yor Hilton. HARVEY tries on outfits for the big show. He pulls a wrin T-shirt over his head and models it for JOYCE who is spre out on the bed surrounded by piles of clothing, scissors sewing supplies. She glances up at Harvey's getup and sha her head no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, c'mon. Who the hell cares?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey tosses his shirt over to Joyce, who snatches it an starts cutting it with a scissor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, whattya doin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merchandising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She resumes her mysterious sewing project; she seems to b making some kind of doll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Backstage, JOYCE watches LATE NIGHT WITH DAVID LETTERMAN a monitor as HARVEY awaits his turn to go on camera. He h changed out of his wrinkled T-shirt into a slightly more  formal look -- a denim shirt and a ratty seersucker strip jacket.

dialogues.speaker: SHOW
dialogues.text: A 1980's DAVID LETTERMAN wisecracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither Joyce nor Harvey look particularly impressed with the whole deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People like this show?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey paces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gettin' hungry back here. They  oughtta leave ya donuts or somethin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nervous STAGE MANAGER wearing a headset peeks his head

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave's ready for you now, Mr. Pekar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you got anything ta eat? My  stomach's growling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking his watch) There's no time to eat now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey glances at the monitor just as Letterman announces his next guest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Our next guest works as a file  clerk in a Cleveland hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stage manager grabs Harvey by the arm. Joyce stops th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Where's the doll?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got it at the desk. Will you  relax about that already?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys, guys, we're in a hurry here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stage Manager physically pushes Harvey out of the Gre Room. Joyce turns back to face the monitor.

dialogues.speaker: MONITOR
dialogues.text: Letterman holds up a copy of a full-size glossy AMERICAN  SPLENDOR ANTHOLOGY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He also writes comic books which  detail his day-to-day pains and  pleasures, and this is an anthology  of nine of those comics. It's entitled  AMERICAN SPLENDOR... From off the  streets of Cleveland, please say  hello to Harvey Pekar.

dialogues.speaker: THE HARVEY PEKAR WHO WALKS ONTO THE SET IS NOT THE ACTOR
dialogues.text: PORTRAYING HIM BUT RATHER THE REAL HARVEY PEKAR (only abo 15 years younger). THIS IS ACTUAL STOCK FOOTAGE FROM HARV FIRST LETTERMAN APPEARANCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce watches as Harvey shakes Letterman's hand and takes seat.

dialogues.speaker: LETTERMAN SHOW
dialogues.text: He smiles as the audience warmly greets him. It seems Har grooving on this attention. But as soon as the audience q down, Harvey turns to his host and starts his offensive:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ready for those Cleveland jokes.  Go ahead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taken off guard, Letterman laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright settle down Harvey. Settle  down. (the Audience laughs) Now let's explain to folks who may  not be familiar with your work what  it is you do here, exactly. You have  comic books about you in your daily  life in Cleveland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And are they embellished at all or  is it pretty much factual?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patronizing) No. It's all true, David. All true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you also have a regular job in  Cleveland working at a hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Aiding the sick, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aiding the sick. Well that's certainly  noble work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unimpressed) Such brilliant repartee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it seems to me Harvey that you  have a very successful career here.  This is being published by a major  publishing company, Doubleday. Why  do you maintain the day job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensive) To make a living! (big laughs) I don't make a living as a writer.  I've been writing for many years,  David. Maybe more years than you've  been alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Letterman cracks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LETTERMAN REGULAR (Tony Randall?) comes in with some fo He stops by the monitor to watch a moment with Joyce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know that my youthful  appearance belies, you know, my actual  age. But, I've been around for a  long time --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to JOYCE) You know this guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm beginning to wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Letterman Regular takes a seat as he watches the moni He seems more intrigued than Joyce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I have a feeling though, if you  wanted to, you could probably get by  on what you make selling your work.  Because I know people are after you  to write other things. You're  publishing this anthology...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This hits a sore spot. Harvey goes from politely condesce to cantankerous in one second flat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? What people? What people? What  are you talking about? Where the  hell do you get that stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Letterman cracks up. The Audience laughs even harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm no show biz phoney. I'm telling  the truth. Come on, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Audience can't believe this guy's holding his own wit Letterman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Joyce) At least he's keeping up with  Letterman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pandering is more like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Joyce walks over to the monitor and looks for t channel. She hits a button, but it only changes the frame the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damnit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, but what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to get some news. You  know there's a big story about to  break about the US selling arms to  Iran and the Contras.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a monitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh. Just forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce gives up. She sinks back into her seat and pulls a  book from her bag. The Letterman Regular stares at her li she's from Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, I know you've got a job.  I've got a job. We're both very lucky.  We both have jobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again laughs and a big round of applause. Letterman  pulls out Joyce's mysterious doll and props it up on the  table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've gotta go. Harvey I like you.  I'm on your side. I enjoy the comic  books. And here, quickly tell us  about the little doll here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife made it.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO JOYCE.
dialogues.text: She suddenly perks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally something good. (to Letterman Regular) Watch this.

dialogues.speaker: LETTERMAN SHOW
dialogues.text: It is an absolutely horrific but oddly evocative "Harvey Doll." His face is inspired by Crumb's drawings of Harvey but even more extreme. His little T-shirt reads, "America Splendor." The Audience is in stitches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're made out of your old clothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do these go for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-four bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked) Thirty-four dollars? Thirty-four  dollars for this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are ya cheap. You cheaper than  me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you pay thirty-four dollars  for that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No but I'm not asking it. My wife  is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOYCE stares at the monitor, expressionless. The STAGE MA sticks his head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a natural.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is. Good stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stage Manager grabs the Regular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon. Your turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smiling HARVEY (the actor now) waltzes in straight from his command performance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whad'ya think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce taps her finger on Letterman's image on the monitor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Megalomaniac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY tries on a ripped T-shirt for Joyce who lies on th bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It became clear pretty fast that I  was invited on the show just for  laughs. But what the hell did I care?  Letterman was an okay guy. Let him  take pot shots at me, s'long as I  got paid an' got to plug my comics.

dialogues.speaker: LETTERMAN SHOW
dialogues.text: MONTAGE: A series of actual HARVEY appearances on LATE NI WITH LETTERMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOYCE, whose different outfits reflect time passage, watc each time from the GREEN ROOM. LETTERMAN SHOW - STOCK FOO HARVEY, in a ratty T-shirt, spars with LETTERMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, you are the embodiment of  the American dream...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Audience laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny thing is, somethin' about me  and Letterman clicked for the viewers.  He kept wantin' me back.

dialogues.speaker: LETTERMAN SHOW
dialogues.text: LETTERMAN introduces his favorite guest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is my pleasure to welcome back  our next guest, the lovable Harvey  Pekar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY walks out with a box of donuts. He starts giving  Letterman an earful right off the bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here was this slick, ambitious guy  with millions, winnin' over the  country by makin' light of everything.  And then there was me... A messy  loser with no dough who takes  everything too seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me Harvey, what do you do to  get away from the pressure of being --  well, a file clerk? (laughter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead and laugh, folks. But he  has more contempt for you than I do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The burger joint has been transformed into a film set wit lights, cameras and lots of trendy MTV types.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An it wasn't just me gettin' all the  attention. As a result of my  appearances on Letterman, my buddy  Toby Radloff landed a gig on MTV  extolling the virtues of White Castle  burgers...

dialogues.speaker: OFF TO THE SIDE
dialogues.text: Two HOT BABES slave over TOBY as he gets his hair and mak up done. HARVEY wanders onto the set. He finally spots Toby in the corner. As he heads over to say hello, Harvey bumps into MTV DIRECTOR -- a new wave fashion victim who looks like lost member of A FLOCK OF SEAGULLS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ! Watch where you're going!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering) Fuckin' yuppie or whatever kinda  freak you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That day on the set with those MTV  jerks, I had an epiphany. It seemed  that real, salt of the earth people  like Toby an' me were bein' coopted  by these huge corporations. We were  gettin' held up and ridiculed as  losers in the system.  What can I  say, it was the 80's man.

dialogues.speaker: MTV PUBLIC SERVICE ANNOUNCEMENT
dialogues.text: TOBY, dressed in dark sunglasses and a turtleneck, stands front of a White Castle. He delivers his lines in his  trademark robotic style. There's an MTV logo on the botto of the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamburgers are a safer addiction  than drugs. Say no to drugs. Say yes  to White Castle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY and JOYCE eat breakfast together. Harvey reads a  Katherine Mansfield book as JOYCE reads a newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up from the  paper) Harvey, I've been reading about these  kids who grew up in war zones...  Palestinians, Israelis, El  Salvadorians, Cambodians... These  kids are amazing and they're --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A YUPPIE in a jogging suit walks up to Harvey, interrupti Joyce in mid-sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you're that guy from the  Letterman show, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Yeah, that's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's so excellent. You and Stupid  Pet Tricks are a riot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey's not smiling anymore. This guy's a jerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Then why dontcha buy one of my  comics, man. That's the only reason  I go on that dumb show anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, sure. Later, Harvey Pekar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Yuppie rushes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, I want to do a political  comic book about these kids. There's  a conference in Jerusalem in a few  weeks, and I can start by doing  interviews there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa whoa, wait a second. Jerusalem?  I can barely drag you off the futon  to go to the Letterman show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know why? 'Cause I don't give a  damn about the Letterman show. I  want to work on something important  to me. Something that matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce hits a nerve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious) Hey! You know I only go on the show  for the extra bread!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People start to look over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey... you're yelling...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe if you got yer lazy ass up and  got a job, I could work on something  that matters, too, huh?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce doesn't dignify Harvey with an answer. She stares a him, her eyes well with hurt. He sighs, calming down. He looks around sheepishly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, baby. I -- I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey and Joyce stroll across the lawn holding hands. Th move towards a waiting cab. Harvey carries his wife's bag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it was good ta finally see  Joyce excited about somethin' of her  own. Sure I was happy for her. But I  was still upset for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop by the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is crazy. Can't ya just do  somethin' here in Cleveland?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, you'll survive a few weeks  alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright... Be careful. I love you,  baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss. Harvey grudgingly puts her bags in the car. He watches as the cab pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was later that night when I first  found the lump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing only his shorts, Harvey lies alone in the communa futon, flipping through a book. He reaches into his under to scratch his nuts. Suddenly he stops. He feels something odd... For a moment he just freezes. His eyes register panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was determined to put it outta my  mind until Joyce got back. Easier  said than done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An enraged HARVEY fights with his co-worker MIGUEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I care! Just gimme the chart  already!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your problem today?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Miguel! I just don't wanna  keep comin' back here for it, okay?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, that patient's due t'be  admitted a week from now! Why do you  always have to be picking fights  with everybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) How many times do we gotta go through  the same bullshit. Just gimme the  fuckin' chart!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Offended, Miguel storms off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see what the doctor says about  this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone and slumped over his table, HARVEY draws comic idea with stick figures. Nothing's coming to him. He looks lik he's in anguish. Frustrated, Harvey crumbles the idea and throws it on the floor. He knocks over a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tosses and turns in bed. No way he's sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY is yelling into the telephone. It is a bad connect

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly into phone) Whadya mean? Another two weeks? Ya  gotta come home some time! Hello?  DAMNIT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without Joyce, a surly Harvey waits in the wings for his  introduction. He sneaks a peek as Letterman finishes up t "stupid pet tricks" segment. We hear dogs barking and aud laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there you have it, folks! Another  enlightening episode of Stupid Pet  Tricks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was startin' ta lose it. Between  the lump, the loneliness -- I felt  like everything wuz closin' in on  me. And with Joyce over there savin'  the world, I never felt more like a  sell-out hack in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know ladies and gentlemen, when  Thoreau wrote that most men lead  lives of quiet depression, he  obviously had not met our first guest,  who happens to lead a life of whining  desperation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey clenches his fists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (threatening) Okay, asshole. You'll pay for that  one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey takes off his shirt. He pulls another t-shirt out the bag and changes ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, please welcome  back, Harvey Pekar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey's new t-shirt reads "ON STRIKE AGAINST NBC." He ta off for the stage, fists clenched, a soldier marching off war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're positioned behind the monitor, so we can only hear show. THE STAGE MANAGER AND TWO PRODUCTION ASSISTANTS  straighten up in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Dave! You wanna know what my  politics are? I'm a strident leftist,  Dave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could have guessed half of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You coulda guessed all of it, man!  So why don't we talk about your parent  company, G.E., huh? Let's talk about  anti-trust violations and nuclear  reactors!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, put more sodas in the fridge,  there. And let's clean up the  counters. That Pekar guy's a pig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the P.A.'s walk back and forth in front of the monitor we hear the Letterman / Pekar banter grow louder. Suddenly PRODUCTION ASSISTANT #2 stops and checks out the monitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa... you guys. Check this out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOBY and his GRANDMOTHER watch HARVEY raise hell on Lette Again, we can't see the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a cop-out, Letterman. You're  nothin' but a shill for G.E.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toby's grandmother passes him a plate of cookies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First of all, Harvey, what you are  saying is not true. Second of all,  this is not the place to say it. If  you want to talk about this, go  somewhere else, because you're not  talking about it here!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dressed in a bathrobe, Mr. Boats eats a lonely, late-nigh snack (cake and milk) at his kitchen table. A 12" TV on t table has Harvey and Dave on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Dave. I won't come back  unless you beg me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not coming back at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I care --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we've given you many, many  chances to talk about things that  would be of general interest to people --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Boats shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Harvey alone, slumped in the back seat of a Town C heading back towards his hotel. City lights pass over his troubled face. We still hear the show, as if it's now in head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- And also to promote your little  Mickey Mouse magazine. Your little  weekly reader! But you've blown every  chance you've got. You're a dork,  Harvey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave, you're fulla shit! You're fulla  shit!!

dialogues.speaker: AN AMERICAN SPLENDOR COMIC
dialogues.text: The cover depicts a snarling LETTERMAN yelling, "YOU FUCK UP A GREAT THING!" at a smirking, self-satisfied HARVEY. JOYCE lies in bed reading the comic, chuckling. HARVEY cu up against her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you did it this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares. He wasn't helpin' my sales  anyway. (moving closer) Baby, don't go away anymore. I just  can't take bein' alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce puts the magazine down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you met those kids over there and  saw what they go through, you wouldn't  ask that of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if you go again I'm really gonna  lose it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not open for discussion, Harvey.  I need this in my life right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cuddles up close to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I do appreciate the fact that  you missed me so much. C'mere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to kiss him. He kisses her back. Her hands wan down. Suddenly she feels something strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, what is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey looks at her and gulps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY and JOYCE sit in the office holding hands, like tw terrified high school kids. A DOCTOR stands before them. They just got bad news...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand, does "tumor"  mean the same thing as "cancer"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor gently nods. Joyce covers her mouth. Harvey holds onto his head. He lo positively dizzy. The doctor starts to talk, yet the word don't seem to match his mouth. He looks dubbed. Strange  phrases just weave together, echo and bounce off the wall making no sense at all. ...we know the growth is malignant. What we don't know is how far it may have spread. Once we have the results of t biopsy, we can make more informed decisions about treatme blah, blah, blah... The whole office seems to spin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce and Harvey sit on the stoop of their apartment hous in a daze. The words keep echoing around them. Harvey hol his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...cat scan... diagnosis... MRI...  cancer... cancer... cancer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I have cancer? I don't feel  sick at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a positive thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My cousin Norman died of lymphoma.  He was twenty-nine. He was a brilliant  oncologist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it! You're not going to die,  Harvey. You're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey turns to Joyce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going to happen to you, baby?  Who's gonna take care of you if I'm  not around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce stands up, determined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey, look at me and focus. We are  going to get through this. I  understand illness. I know how to  handle these things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's you. I'm not strong enough.  I don't know how ta be positive. I  can't do it. I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you can. And I'll tell you how.  You'll make a comic book out of the  whole thing. You'll document every  little detail. And that way you'll  remove yourself from the experience  until it's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Despite Joyce's passionate pitch, Harvey shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do that. I'm just not strong  enough... I just wanna die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce folds her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. I'll do it without you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY and JOYCE lay there quietly, both exhausted. Joyce turns over so her back faces Harvey. He puts his arm arou her.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE'S FACE
dialogues.text: A tear drips down her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce is straightening up the apartment. The place actual looks halfway decent.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOORBELL RINGS
dialogues.text: Joyce opens the door. A guy in his 30's named FRED -- Hel Angels tough guy meets sensitive artist -- stands at the  door. He's accompanied by a seven-year-old girl, DANIELLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm Fred. You called me about  the comic book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right -- the artist. Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my daughter, Danielle. I had  to bring her along. I hope you don't  mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce leans down and addresses the girl, who holds a toy  horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Danielle. What's that you're  holding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's immediately obvious that Joyce is great with kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pony? What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a girl. Clarissa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see. Well, I'm Joyce. Nice to  meet both you and Clarissa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all walk towards the table which is covered with pap

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really sorry to hear about Harvey.  Is he here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going to work until next week,  when he starts the chemo. That's why  I wanna get this project started  now. Once he's stuck here, I know  he'll take over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miserable and in a daze, HARVEY walks up to his front doo He looks like a man whose days are numbered. When he reac the door, he searches his pockets for keys.

dialogues.speaker: POCKET
dialogues.text: Harvey's hand comes up empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey tries the doorknob, but it's locked. He steps back on the lawn and looks around. Could he have dropped them? He retraces a few steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damnit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey yells up at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce, open the door! I lost my keys  again! Joyce!!

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: HARVEY'S ELDERLY NEIGHBOR struggles with her shopping car through the door. Harvey pushes past her to get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey knocks again. Nothing. Now he punches the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce!! Open the fucking door!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the door opens. Loud music pours out. But it's n Joyce, it's FRED, the artist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey just stares at him. Fred opens the door to reveal: JOYCE and DANIELLE dancing together with the stereo blast They're having a ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the kitchen table, HARVEY looks over FRED'S sketches. JOYCE and DANIELLE are now building a house of cards on t living room floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here are some ideas we batted around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheesh. Joyce doesn't know what she's  doing. There's too many words in  these frames. When are ya comin'  back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, she said something about next  Tuesday, which is fine with me. Only  thing is, I might have the kid again.  My ex-wife's supposed to take her,  but I don't have much faith in her  showing up. She is in worse shape  than me these days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey looks away at Joyce and Danielle playing. They're  oblivious to the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next week my treatment begins. Do me  a favor. Bring the kid with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRED'S PENCIL completes a sketch of Joyce pushing Harvey a wheelchair. The word "cancer" appears everywhere, float all around the image.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The following montage chronicles Harvey's illness by cutt between comic art depicting key events and shots of HARVE JOYCE and FRED creating the book. The montage is set to the simultaneously dulcet and disco tone of Miles Davis' "Blue in Green" (or something simila

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on Harvey's face as he's getting pushed down the ha in a wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A panel of Harvey entering the M.R.I. machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Harvey, Joyce and Fred sitting around a table. Joy fights to keep Harvey focused on the project.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1) An enraged Harvey throws things around the house. 2) Joyce on the bed crying, a cat licking her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A balding Harvey depressed in the shower. He holds a clum of hair in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey in the shower. The balloon above his head reveals inner turmoil over losing his hair and his face swelling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey in agony. Various positions of him in bed, on all  fours, covered with a case of shingles. "I feel like I'm fire" appears over his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce and Fred go over some more comic art. Joyce carries the idea over to Harvey (wearing a baseball cap), who can get out of the couch. He looks it over and nods. Danielle brings Harvey a glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey crawling up the steps. "I'm so weak I can't make i he thinks... Harvey and Joyce in a hospital waiting room. He's slumped over, she has her hand on him. A delirious Harvey surrounded by nurses and Joyce. "She's torturing me, she won't let me die, I wanna die..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A balding Harvey lies on his bathroom floor. His cat walk all over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna die... just let me die...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce attempts to wake Harvey up. She curses at him. She  slaps him. "Why are you doing this to me!" A drawing of Joyce, doubled over, crying. "I can't take t anymore..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A repeat of the opening scene... Like a ghost, a naked HA stands over his bed staring down at a sleeping JOYCE. In the eerie light, he's almost translucent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faintly) Joyce... Joyce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce springs up, alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong, Harvey? What are you  doing up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey just stands there for a moment saying nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delirious, out of  breath) Tell me the truth. Am I some guy who  writes about himself in a comic book?  Or am I just -- just a character in  that book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harvey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I die, will 'dat character keep  goin'? Or will he just fade away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce just stares at him, unsure how to answer. Finally H collapses. Joyce leaps from the bed, nervous, hysterical. She gets d on the floor and shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Omigod, Harvey! Harvey, wake up!

dialogues.speaker: HARVEY'S FACE
dialogues.text: His eyes remain closed, his expression far, far away. The sound of Joyce's voice fades until it seems like a distan echo. Then PANELS from Harvey's comics begin to float over his  head, his life literally passing before his eyes in comic book form. Slowly, the comic images and the unconscious Harvey evapo giving way to:

dialogues.speaker: A SURREAL DREAM SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: We are now in a large, empty room similar to a blank comi book panel. A healthy, fully dressed Harvey appears in the corner of frame. He is very far away, barely recognizable. We slowl dolly towards him as he delivers a formal soliloquy to th camera:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Harvey Pekar. It's an  unusual name -- Harvey Pekar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Harvey speaks, one-dimensional comic book images from life pass over the screen once again. This time in front him, behind him, everywhere. We dolly in towards him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1960 was the year I got my first  apartment and my first telephone  book. Imagine my surprise when I  looked up my name and saw that, in  addition to me, another Harvey Pekar  was listed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Images of Harvey's childhood float by, followed by his yo adult years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was listed as Harvey L. Pekar...  My middle name is Lawrence... He was  listed as Harvey Pekar -- no middle  initial... Therefore, his was a purer  listing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Harvey age in the images: he's hanging on the stre corner with friends, collecting records, hanging with Cru

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, in the seventies, I noticed  that a third Harvey Pekar was listed  in the phone book! This filled me  with curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could there be three people with  such an unusual name in the world,  let alone in one city?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, numerous images of Harvey's many years at the V.A.  Hospital float by: Harvey filing, Harvey arguing with his boss, Harvey and Toby, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then one day, a person I worked with  expressed her sympathy to me  concerning what she thought was the  death of my father. She pointed out  an obituary notice in the newspaper  for a man named Harvey Pekar. One of  his sons was named Harvey. These  were the other Harvey Pekars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The comic images fade out. Harvey is once again alone in empty room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six months later, Harvey Pekar Jr.  died. Although I'd met neither man,  I was filled with sadness. "What  were they like," I thought. It seemed  that our lives had been linked in  some indefinable way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We slowly move in on his face. Extremely close. As close the camera can get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the story does not end there.  For two years later another Harvey  Pekar appeared in the directory.  What kind of people are these? Where  do they come from, what do they do?  What's in a name?

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO BEDROOM
dialogues.text: We are close on HARVEY'S face as he lays passed out and  delirious on the floor. Over this WE HEAR...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is Harvey Pekar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face slowly fades to black. A MOMENT OF BLACK, AND THEN...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scrawled across the top in yellow and red it read, "Our C Year." The drawing depicts Harvey doubled over on the fro lawn, groceries in the snow, with Joyce attempting to hel him up. A hand flips the book open and signs the inside l JOYCE and a healthy-looking HARVEY sit at a table signing copies of their opus. About fifteen or so people mill abo with copies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's our man a year later. Somehow  I made it through the treatments,  an' the doctors are optimistic. I  guess Joyce was right about doin'  the big comic book. We published the  thing as a graphic novel -- our first  collaboration -- and ended up with  rave reviews. We even won the American  Book Award. Go figure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is still a mess but somehow it has a better vib than it had before. This might be due to the presence of  DANIELLE. She sits crossed legged on the floor making jew out of beads. JOYCE guides her. HARVEY shuffles into the room. He watches for a moment as Joyce and Danielle play. ANGLE ON JOYCE: There is an awkward expression almost  resembling a smile on her face. He interrupts them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Joyce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce looks up. Harvey looks like he's trying to hide  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it Harvey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was the doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joyce stops what she's doing and gulps. She hangs on Harv every word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said I'm all clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears well in Harvey's eyes. Joyce breathes a sigh of rel and Danielle jumps up and runs over to Harvey. She hugs h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY sits in the bleachers, watching JOYCE teach DANIEL to ice skate. Harvey's got a box of pizza next to him. He picks up a sl and chomps on it. The cheese drips out of his mouth onto shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The weirdest thing that came outta  my illness was Danielle. With her  real mother runnin' around who knows  where, an' seein' how well her and  Joyce got on, Fred decided she'd  have a better life with us. I was  scared at first but then I thought,  what the hell. She's a good kid. So  we ended up takin' her an' raising  her as our own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY and DANIELLE lie on the futon together. Harvey's c are strewn around the room everywhere. Danielle flips thr one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya keep readin' 'em backward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like reading them backward. (holding up a comic) Is that you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I keep tellin' ya, all of 'ems me,  man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like a monster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well wait'll ya see what you're  gonna look like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Yer part of the story too,  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The story of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danielle makes a face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know I'm not as interesting  as The Little Mermaid and all that  magical crap...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I want to write my own comic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? What about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know yet. But not about you.  You have enough already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY walks towards the bus stop to send DANIELLE to sch He holds her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya know, you should write about things  in your own life. Like school and...  ponies... I don't know, girl stuff...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Harvey) Do you have to hold my hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wounded) What, are you embarrassed a' me? I  know, I'm embarrassing. I felt the  same way about my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danielle looks up at Harvey like he's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Harvey. You're just squeezing it  too hard. (shaking her head) Joyce is right. You are obsessive  compulsive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danielle drops his hand and rushes onto the bus with othe kids. Harvey waves and watches as it pulls away. He turns and walks by himself down the busy Cleveland str -- a familiar image from the opening. He's still hunched  over. He's still Harvey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, so I guess comics brought me a  lot. But don't think this is some  sunny, happy ending. Every day is  still a major struggle. Joyce an' I  fight like crazy, an' she barely  works. The kid's got A.D.D. and is a  real handful. My expenses have gone  up so much that I'm writin' freelance  'round the clock, just to make my  bills. My life is total chaos.

dialogues.speaker: DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE
dialogues.text: NOW THE REAL HARVEY walks down the same busy Cleveland st towards his job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a little luck, I'll get a window  of good health between retirin' an  dyin'. The golden years, right? Who  knows. Between my pension and the  chunk of change I got for this movie,  I should be able to swing somethin'.  Sure I'll lose the war eventually,  but the goal is to win a few  skirmishes along the way. Right?

dialogues.speaker: DOCUMENTARY FOOTAGE
dialogues.text: THE REAL HARVEY slumps at the desk now, flipping through comic book.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: THE REAL TOBY comes into the file room, carrying a cake w sparklers. He's followed by a group of Harvey's REAL COWO and JOYCE and REAL DANIELLE. Harvey moves the comic off his desk so Toby can put the c down.

dialogues.speaker: CAKE
dialogues.text: The festive cake reads "HAPPY RETIREMENT HARVEY." REAL JO cuts the cake and passes slices to the group. ANOTHER WORKER pops a bottle of champagne. CLOSE on a glass of champagne getting filled. The glass s next to the comic Harvey was reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARVEY'S new edition of AMERICAN SPLENDOR is subtitled, " MOVIE YEAR." It features an illustration of HARVEY, JOYCE and DANIELLE surrounded by cameras, lights and crew.
